title: Australia survive more high-tackle controversy to brush aside Uruguay
text:
Michael Cheika was unhappy with his side's lack of discipline after Australia's 45-10 victory over Uruguay but refused to specifically discuss Australia's ongoing problem with high tackle penalties, after the Wallabies gave away four in the first half, leading to yellow cards for Adam Coleman and Lukhan Salakaia-Loto.

Australia conceded 12 penalties in total compared to just five by Uruguay, with Cheika lamenting another slow start from the Wallabies, having also trailed Wales at half-time by 15 points.

"We are giving away too many penalties full stop," Cheika said. "You can’t be winning by 45 and still lose the penalty count, we’ve got to stop giving away penalties. One was for kicking the ball out of a ruck. That’s a penalty and we know that. We have to tidy that up. But I’m not going to talk about tackles, I’m going to steer clear of that.

"The one thing we need to be mindful of is that we have not started games well. It is not that we have not played well, we have just been a little less consistent in the first 20 minutes. It gets you off on the wrong foot, so it is definitely something that we need to address."

Wallabies captain Michael Hooper backed up Cheika's point, adding that losing two players to yellow cards in the first half had disrupted Australia's rhythm.
